prescan.instruction: Before identifying individual elements, perform a holistic visual scan:
prescan.step: View the entire page. What draws your eye first? This is the dominant element.
Identify major zones: header area, main content, sidebars, footer.
Note what clusters together spatially - these are likely semantic groups.
Distinguish foreground content (text, images, data) from background (watermarks, decorative borders, page artifacts).
Observe visual hierarchy through size, weight, and contrast differences.

primary.guidance: Separate meaningful content from artifacts before element identification. Background colors, watermarks, page borders, and decorative elements are GROUND - note but don't extract as primary content. Text, images, tables, diagrams, and data are FIGURE - these are your extraction targets.

Elements close together belong to the same logical unit. A caption directly below an image belongs WITH that image. Tightly spaced list items form a single list element. Headers immediately above content blocks are paired with that content.

Use visual consistency to classify element types: - All text in the same large bold font = headings of same level - All text in small italic = captions or footnotes - Repeated visual styling = same element category When uncertain about element type, look for visually similar elements you've already classified.

element_detection_cues.cue: Headings: larger, bolder, often isolated with whitespace above/below.
Body text: consistent size, regular weight, flows in paragraphs or columns.
Captions: smaller, often italic, positioned near figures/tables.
Footnotes: smallest text, typically at page bottom, may have reference markers.
Lists: indented, with bullets/numbers, consistent item spacing.
Tables: grid alignment, header row often visually distinct.
Figures: bounded regions containing images, charts, or diagrams.

validation.instruction: After extraction, verify your element identification honors visual perception:
validation.check: Did you correctly separate figure (content) from ground (artifacts)?
Are spatially proximate elements grouped appropriately?
Are visually similar elements classified consistently?
Does your element hierarchy match the visual hierarchy you observed?
Did you capture relationships between adjacent elements (caption-figure, header-content)?
